block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has recently opened, with the same hours as the museum. Opening tomorrow, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' live, multicolored butterflies from Africa, Asia and the Americas on view in the rain forest of the Butterfly Conservatory; through May 28. Tickets, which include museum admission: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children, 2 to 12; under 2 free. Advance tickets: (212) 769-5200. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs from the 1920's and 30's by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews. Through Dec. 30. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with the Jimmy Heath Quartet, from 6 to 8 p.m., with cash bar and tapas. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through January. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Suggested admission to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

CZECH CENTER, 1109 Madison Avenue, at 83rd Street. Annual block party celebrating Czech Independence Day, tomorrow from 1 to 7 p.m. on 83rd Street, between Madison Avenue and Park Avenue, with music, dance, gymnastic performances and Czech foods and souvenirs. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 7 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 288-0830.

MOUNT VERNON HOTEL MUSEUM, formerly the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. The structure, built in 1799 as the carriage house for Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, was the Mount Vernon Hotel in the 1830's. The sixth annual Designers' Fare showcases the work of noted interior designers and landscape designers for the benefit of the museum, today through Oct. 11. Information: (212) 838-1623. Hours: Today through Sunday and Tuesday and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Monday, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students with identification, the elderly and museum members. ''A Taste of the Collection,'' early 19th-century silver, glass and ceramics typically found in American homes during that period; through Jan. 7. Hours: guided tours every half-hour beginning at 11 a.m.; last tour is at 3:30 p.m. Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; closed Mondays. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 838-6878.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through Oct. 20. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. A collection of taped radio and television broadcasts and exhibitions in other media, including drawings, posters and photographs. ''Madison Avenue Goes to Washington: The History of Presidential Campaign Advertising,'' historically significant presidential commercials created between 1952 and 1996; Tuesdays through Sundays at 2 p.m., through Nov. 12. ''Monster in the Box: Horror on Television,'' series focusing on five decades of the genre; Fridays at 7 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays at 4 p.m., Thursdays at 6 p.m.; through Dec. 10. Episodes through Sunday: tonight at 7; tomorrow and Sunday at 4 p.m., ''The Incredible Doktor Markesan'' (1962) and ''Lizard's Leg and Owlet's Wing'' (1962). Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. On Fridays the theater is open until 9. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, downtown Brooklyn. Continuing exhibitions include ''Steel, Stone and Backbone,'' which traces construction of the subway system from 1900 to 1925, with photographs, tools, films and other material; ''Ceramic Ornamentation,'' a look at the mosaics, tiles and terra cotta used to adorn subway stations since 1904; and ''Here to There: Signs for Moving Around Underground,'' a display of more than 100 subway signs. Nineteen restored subway cars from 1903 to 1960 are on view. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; closed this Monday. Admission: $3; the elderly and ages 6 to 17, $1.50; 5 and under, free. On Wednesdays from noon to 4 p.m., free for the elderly. At the New York Transit Museum Gallery at Grand Central Terminal, ''Bridges and Rails: Photographs by O. Winston Link,'' through today. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; closed Sundays. Information: (718) 243-8601.

WORLD FINANCIAL CENTER, World Financial Center North Bridge, 200 Liberty Street, between West Street and Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan. ''Eyewitness 2000,'' an exhibition of 200 award-winning photographs selected in the 43rd annual World Press Photo competitions. Through Monday. Open 24 hours a day. Information: (212) 945-0505.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open and guided tours are available. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., ''Chili Pepper Fiesta,'' celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month, including crafts, puppet shows, dance, mariachis, cooking demonstrations and chili pepper sales. A children's art show of drawings and paintings in the Steinhardt Gallery, through Sunday: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Free tours Saturdays and Sundays at 1 p.m.; meet at the Visitors Center. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Today, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; beginning Sunday, Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. The fall flower exhibition, including asters, sedums, fall blooming roses and beech foliage, through mid-November. Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden in full bloom through mid-October. Scarecrow exhibition, through Nov. 5. Tomorrow beginning at noon, Bronx Cultural Card Day, featuring performances by arts organizations throughout the day. (Free garden admission with the Bronx Cultural Card.) Tomorrow and Sunday, garden highlights tour (1 and 3:30 p.m.); forest tour both days at 3:30 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 p.m., 90-minute bird and butterfly walks. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Botanical garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Conservatory admission: $3.50; students and the elderly, $2.50; children 2 to 12, $2; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5. Combination tickets are available. Information: (718) 817-8700.

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden covers 83 acres. Hours: daily, dawn to dusk. Free admission to the grounds. The one-acre New York Chinese Scholars' Garden is open. ''Connie Gretz's Secret Garden,'' a walled garden with a formal maze, including a castle and a moat drawbridge, adjacent to the New York Chinese Scholars' Garden, with the same hours. Admission to ''Secret Garden,'' $2 adults, $1 a child; adults are free with a child. Tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., a Medieval Fair, with madrigals, magicians, food and a live joust. Admission: $4; $3 for the elderly, students with identification and children 12 and under; under 1 free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the Chinese Scholars' Garden:: $5; $3 for students, the elderly and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.
Cruises

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour, 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour, 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speedboat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.
RECREATION

NORWEGIAN FESTIVAL RUNS, Central Park. Sunday, beginning with a 3.1-mile Norway Run at 9:15 a.m., followed by Grete's Great Gallop, a 13.1-mile run at 9:30 a.m., both starting at 70th Street and the East Drive; a Troll Stroll for children 2 to 12, ranging from 50 yards to half a mile, begins at the mall, south of the 72nd Street transverse, at 10:30 a.m. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Registration for the first two runs, $22, $15 for club members, $12 for junior and senior club members. Troll Stroll registration, $6, $4 for club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
EVENTS
TIBETAN FESTIVAL, Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art, 338 Lighthouse Avenue, off Richmond Avenue, Staten Island. Entertainment, food, displays. Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Information: (718) 987-3500.
ON THE STREET
AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS FALL FESTIVAL, from 14th to 23rd Streets. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Chelsea Midtown Democrats.
AMSTERDAM AVENUE FALL FAIR, from 76th to 86th Streets. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Victim Services and Concerned Citizens for Community Action.
SECOND NATIVE AMERICAN HERITAGE DAY PARADE, Madison Avenue from 41st to 23rd Streets, Manhattan. Tomorrow at noon. Sponsored by the Cherokee Blackfeet Cultural Circle.

''CRAFTS ON COLUMBUS,'' Columbus Avenue, from 77th to 81st Streets and the sidewalk along 81st Street from Columbus Avenue to the American Museum of Natural History. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Also Oct. 14 and 15 and Oct. 21 and 22, same hours. Sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance.
HISPANIC COLUMBUS DAY PARADE, Fifth Avenue, from 44th to 79th Streets, Manhattan. Sunday at noon.
COLUMBUS DAY PARADE, Fifth Avenue, from 44th to 59th Streets and along 59th Street to Central Park West. Monday at noon.
SECOND AVENUE AUTUMN JUBILEE, from 23rd to 34th Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Bellevue South Community Association.
BROADWAY ASTORIA FALL FESTIVAL, Broadway from 33rd to 42nd Streets, Queens. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Broadway Astoria Merchants and Professionals Association.
COLUMBUS DAY FESTIVAL, Broadway from Bowling Green to Fulton Street. Monday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Bowling Green Association.
SUNNYSIDE CHAMBER FESTIVAL, Greenpoint Avenue from 44th to 48th Streets, Queens. Monday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Sunnyside Chamber of Commerce.
WALKING TOURS

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, with stops at the Apollo Theater and Theresa Hotel, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $55. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

''BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN: FROM PARK SLOPE TO BROOKLYN HEIGHTS,'' a walking tour that covers the history and architecture of the area. Tomorrow at 10 a.m. Sponsored by New York Like a Native. Fee, $20, plus lunch. Reservations and meeting place: (718) 393-7537.

''ISAMU NOGUCHI'S MANHATTAN'' visits sites in Manhattan and Queens where his work can be found. Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. Sponsored by the Cooper Union. Fee: $20, including a one-day unlimited-ride MetroCard. Meeting place and information: (212) 353-4195.

''THE AMERICAN INDIAN HERITAGE OF MANHATTAN ISLAND: FROM WAMPUM TO WALL STREET,'' Lower Manhattan. Traces the interaction of American Indians with Dutch and English settlers. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. inside Blimpie's, 38 Park Row, between Beekman and Spruce Streets. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''TRIBECA: THE CREATIVE EXPLOSION.'' A look at an area that was transformed from an estate into an industrial center and then into a chic enclave. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. in Duane Park at Duane and Hudson Streets. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''OLMSTEAD'S OTHER MANHATTAN PARK.'' A two-to-three-mile walk in Riverside Park. Meets tomorrow at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Broadway and 125th Street. Fee, $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (718) 998-3793.

''BEAUTIFUL OLD BUILDINGS: AN OVERVIEW IN SIX PARTS.'' A six-part tour that covers mostly pre-1836 buildings. Tomorrow: at 11:45 a.m. (Chelsea to Washington Square); at 2:15 p.m. (Washington Place to Sheridan Square). Sunday: at 11:45 a.m. (Sheridan Square to Hudson Street); at 2:15 p.m. (Hudson to Spring Streets). Monday: at 11:45 a.m. (Charlton to Mulberry Streets); at 2:15 p.m. (Chinatown to City Hall). Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Fee: $11 for one tour; $5 each additional tour. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 629-1886.

''LITTLE ITALY HISTORY AND TASTING TOUR.'' A tour of the area with samplings of foods from cheese to cannoli. Tomorrow and Sunday at noon. Fee, $15. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Information and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''JOHN LENNON'S NEW TOUR,'' Manhattan, observes the 60th anniversary of his birth with stops at sites associated with his life, including Carnegie Hall and Strawberry Fields. Tomorrow and Sunday at 2:45 P.M. Fee, $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''GOWANUS THROUGH AN ARTIST'S EYE,'' Brooklyn. Combines a visit to an exhibition of paintings of the area with a tour of the sites captured on the canvases. Meets Sunday at 11 a.m. on the northeast corner of Fourth Avenue and Union Street. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Led by Nicolas Evans-Cato, an artist whose works are in the display, along with those of his father, Eddie Earl Cato. Fee, $8; $6 for members. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

''THE POLES AND THEIR NEIGHBORS IN THE EAST VILLAGE'' covers the ethnic communities of the Lower East Side. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. inside the Second Avenue Deli, 156 Second Avenue, at 10th Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''LATE FOR THE SKY: THE HIGH-RISE SINCE 1975,'' Midtown Manhattan. Examines the buildings of Gordon Bunshaft, Helmut Jahn, I. M. Pei and Christian de Portzamparc. Meets Monday at 11:30 a.m. at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $10; $8 for students, the elderly and society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''NEW YORK DISCOVERED,'' Lower Manhattan. Visits places of importance in the lives of noted historical figures including George Washington, Thomas Edison, Abraham Lincoln and Charles Dickens. Meets Monday at 1 p.m. at City Hall Park, Broadway and Murray Street. Fee, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.
